reviewText: This concert DVD is a compilation of other Ringo and His All-Star band tour DVD's.  This is the one to own, if you are a child of the 60s and enjoy classic rock.  You get to see great live performances from Levon Helm, Dr. John, John Entwistle, Joe Walsh, Ringo and his son Zack.  But, by far are the performances by Felix Cavaliere of The Rascals and the rock treasure Gary Brooker of Procol Harum.  Not to mention Mark Farner of Grand Funk.  You won't even be let down by Ringo's road band either.  All in all great fun.  This one belongs in everyone's personal rock archives.
summary: GREAT LIVE PERFOMANCES FROM ROCK GREATS
Title: N/A

reviewText: Most of the material on this DVD was originally released on VHS.  I was very impressed by the audio quality of many of the tracks based on how old the recordings are.  The video is a little grainy and color washed out but overall I was pleasantly surprised by the DVD.  The members of the bands that have joined Ringo over the years are all remarkable entertainers.  The list of the individual stars on this DVD is unbelievable.  It has some classic songs that love and the Jack Bruce, Peter Frampton set on the Cream tune "Sunshine of Your Love" is remarkable.If you are a fan of music from the 1970's and of course a former Beatle, check out the material available on this DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Wow wow wow I wish I could have seen some of these shows live!I first got turned on to Ringo's All Starr tours in 1991 and have been to several of their concerts since then.They're always some of the most fun shows; nothing like seeing a diverse bunch of musicians having fun taking turns playing their hits for fans. Every RS All Starr show I've been to has turned into a sing-along and love & peace fest....exactly what you expect from Ringo.But how I wish I'd seen the earlier shows on this DVD!The earliest shows feature Clarence Clemons, Nils Lofgren, Dr. John, Levon Helm, Richard Danko, Todd Rundgren, Billy Preston and more...if you're an old rock fan like me you'll treasure seeing these talented artists perform together.And it's so obvious they're having a blast doing it!It's not just one concert on this but highlights from a few different years and in a few different venues.It's fun watching the different band line-ups and seeing how the show evolved from year to year.I have tickets to go see the current All Starr's in October and can't wait!I'm not going to get into the technical specs because I don't speak it well...but played on my Blu-Ray player that upscales through my home theater system it sounded great.Yeah some of the early footage isn't super sharp but IMHO that's ok because it's the way things were back then. I like the authenticity.I've got few other DVD's of the All Starrs from more recent years and this one is my fave so far.It's a real piece of rock history and a "must have" for Ringo fans and fans of the other artists; especially if you never saw some of them live while they were still with us.
summary: Seen RS & All Starrs several times...wish I'd seen this live!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: A real treat, I just expected this to be so, so, but what a find.  Jack Bruce and Peter Frampton are dynamite during their Sunshine session.  Also rediscovered Gary Brooker of Procol Harum, how cool is he, VERY!Its so nice to see musicians appearing to truly enjoy what they are doing,having a great time and connecting with the audience.Seeing this DVD pushed me out to see Ringo and his all star band last year when they came by, and that was one of the most magical, take you back concerts I have ever had the pleasure of seeing.downside, did not enjoy Dr John, guess he is an acquired taste,and thought they could have let Peter Frampton do something more than Norwegian Wood, he could have Shown us the Way.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Good audio and video.  Only thing that would have made it better would have been to have more songs by the other band members.  For instance, they did no songs by Billy Preston.  I guess that's what you get with a compilation.  That's ok - it's still a fine DVD.

reviewText: I saw ringo in jax fla. in 2000 and this dvd is a great souvenier of that show.However the sound quality is not quite what I expected.Some of the instruments were not miked enough to hear.DTS was impressive but not as much as Steely Dans 2 against nature.All in all it is a good representation of the good old days of rock.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is really what rock and roll is all about.  Dumb, loud fun.Ringo Starr goes out just about each summer, with a band of old rockers that still (like Ringo himself) have a lot of kick left in them despite the lack of greying hair most of them display.  It's not great art (and really, if rock and roll is great art you're doing it wrong) and it's not always letter-perfect, but it's always 2 hours of fun.For those that don't go to the shows (and honestly, why not?), this generous DVD gives a sampling of the last 10 years of shows.  And it's quite a line-up of greats and near-greats: Jack Bruce, Todd Rundgren, members of the Band, Dr. John, Joe Walsh and on and on.Never, ever are these old boys coasting, they're giving it all they've got on every track.  And look, if you're over 40, it's 2 hours of your favorite songs played by the guys that made them hits - and all with the steadiest drummer in the business backing them up.Rock and roll is supposed to be loud, dumb and fun, and this is that and more - especially since it's clear to the viewer that the bands are having tons of fun doing this.I wonder how many of today's hot-shots will be able to do this kind of thing in 20 years?  These cats have NOT gotten old, and you'll truly enjoy spending 2 hours with Ringo and his All-Starrs.
summary: It's just like a live jukebox
Title: N/A

reviewText: This would have been a great DVD compilation of Hall of Fame rock n' roll talent except it was missing one star that nearly stole the show night after night while they toured thru 1995 and early 96......Grand Funk's Mark Farner was for some reason not included in any of the showcases even though he was a main cog in Ringo's 3rd Allstar installment...He's in the background on some of the tunes of others,but it's still a huge slight to a great fore-runner of the hard rock/heavy metal genre.It was his face on this tour that helped launch the Mark, Don & Mel reunion of Grand Funk Railroad in 96-98....But for some silly reason, not important enough to make the cut with this DVD production.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is The Ringo and His All*Stars best, highlighting all of the tours best material from five tours. I was lucky to catch the final group set on this DVD in Mesa, Arizona. I understand that there was so much material to choose from, but I sure wish Ringo would have included Frampton covering his own tunes. Frampton and Bruce do battle with bass and guitar and it's VERY GOOD, but when I saw them, Jack Bruce did a fantastic bass lead break that lasted about 10 minutes. The band had left the stage for water and cool towels. I thought the way the band acted, it was an unplanned break. Evidently, I was right.If you get a chance to see Ringo, do it! If not, this DVD will pacify you. It is much better than the other Ringo DVDs that are from one tour.
summary: Do yourself a favor, buy this one!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ringo Starr has always been a great showman with his wit and humor.  However, Ringo's performances are probably not the reason to consider the purchase of this DVD.  For me, it was seeing Felix Cavaliere doing the Rascals' classic "Groovin" and Jack Bruce doing "Sunshine of Your Love" with Peter Frampton.  While I never really put "A Whiter Shade of Pale" into my top 50 all time favorite songs, I gained new appreciation for the piece after seeing it performed by Gary Brooker.  Some other pleasant surprises were Randy Bachman doing "You Aint Seen Nothin Yet" and Levon Helm doing "The Weight."  Ringo's performances were sort of Las Vegas-like---he's generally not playing the drums when he sings but rather is in front of his bandmates  with a microphone singing his favorites.  I personally hope Ringo continues to put these tours together---some of these bandmembers can still turn out some awsome performances, and the audience seems to always have a blast.  "A splendid time is guaranteed for all."
summary: Any classic rock fan will enjoy this!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD is sensational.  Every performer on here is a rock legend.  I own all the VHS tapes from these individual tours, and I'm very glad to own this "best of" release, which captures all tours between 1989 and 1997 on film, including the 1995 tour which was not released individually on VHS like the other three, and thus hasn't been seen on video until now.  Highlights for me include a rocking "Iko Iko" by Dr. John, an excellent rendition of Joe Walsh's "Rocky Mountain Way," and Jack Bruce singing "Sunshine of Your Love."  Also the big man himself (Ringo) gives many splendid renditions of classic Beatles songs as well as some of his own hits.This DVD is a marvelous compilation in every way.  I also highly recommend the companion 3-CD set, as it showcases even more fine work from these very talented performers.  (Also the CDs include music from the 2000 All-Starr tour, which was completely left off this DVD.)
Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD is comprised of footage, much of it released for the first time on DVD, taken between 1989 and 1997 of Ringo and his All-Starr Band.  I love the performances on this DVD, which shows Ringo and the rest giving it all they've got.  My favorites are "Photograph (Ringo)," "Iko Iko (Dr. John)," and "Don't Go Where The Road Don't Go (Ringo)."  The bands all sound energized and youthful, with a lot of fun pouring out of every song.  On top of that, they really knew how to rock.
summary: All I've Got is a Photograph...And Thankfully, This DVD!

reviewText: Ringo is well advised to stay behind the drumskins.  He can't dance and has no rhythm.  After watching a few of his songs, I skipped the rest.  Highlights of this DVD most certanly are songs done with his guests.  The Weight, You Ain't Seen Nothin' Yet, Sunshine of Your Love, Norwegian Wood and Whiter Shade Of Pale are particularly well done.  Lowlights were Photograph (especially grievous) and Joe Walsh's Rocky Mountain Way which was basically played for a joke.  I got this one used and only for a few bucks but I would have been particularly mad if I had paid full price.  I don't recommend it.

reviewText: I felt I was taking a chance on this purchase. Guess I was, but was wildly surprised!!!  I never was a big Beatle fan nor especially a Ringo fan.  Ringo has lent his name to a GREAT DVD.  What an opportunity to see and hear some of the LEGENDS of rock and roll.  Great sounds and song selections.  Ringo even sings one (Don't Go Where The Road Don't Go) that should be a big hit TODAY!!!!  Get this disk and crank it up!!!!

reviewText: The drumming of Ringo especially in his Beatles days was a master of understatement and efficiency. Sadly little of that is on show here with either excessive use of drummers (the Greek Theater  set with three drummers and two on all others) or an overcrowded supergroup (typified by the Montreux concert numbers).Also his backing of a number of artistes whose overblown style dominates (Joe Walsh, Randy Bachmann and Todd Rundgren being the main exponents)leaves him very much in the background on a number of occasions. Coupled with a stage presence when lead singing which is closer to a sing along karaoke style, the only option is to enjoy the high spots when they do occur.Dr John, Levon Helm and Felix Cavaliere shine in the earlier sets but the star performance is reserved for the 1997 sessions from Pine Knob, where Ringo with a mostly British band (Simon Kirke, Peter Frampton, Jack Bruce, Gary Brooker) turns in a string of strong versions that really burn.Overall a bit disappointing and one where after a few plays the "skip control is getting used I must admit.
summary: Ringo in karaoke style surrounded by superstars
